title: Wonga and QuickQuid under the microscope at City watchdog
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Sep 14, 2015, 18:38 BST - UK Markets closed Wonga and QuickQuid under the microscope at City watchdog By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 2 minutes 32 seconds ago Print 
Regulators are paying much closer attention to a group of the biggest and most high-profile payday lenders before they hand out full licences to the firms 
High-profile payday lenders Wonga and QuickQuid are among a group of loan firms and debt management businesses facing extra scrutiny from regulators before they are given the all-clear on their new licences to operate. 
The enhanced authorisation process will see the group of consumer credit firms face at least two panels of regulators at the Financial Conduct Authority, rather than one, and could see their cases escalated up the chain of command to the most senior executives at the watchdog. 
Officials are understood to be keen to make sure the very biggest players in the sector are investigated most rigorously before they get final approval, in part because any problems at those major firms would have an impact on tens or even hundreds of thousands of customers. 
The FCA took over regulation of the 50,000 firms in the consumer credit sector in April 2014, giving interim permission to the firms at first. 
Over time the regulator is looking into each sub-sector of the industry, studying the firms and, where appropriate, offering full authorisation for them to offer their services to the public. 
This process has already begun with those industries deemed to be the riskiest to customers , including payday lenders, credit brokerages and log book lenders. 
More than 5,000 such firms have already dropped out of the process before applying for full permission, some because their business models may not have withstood the scrutiny of the FCA, and others because the lending arm was a small part of their business for example, dentists or car dealerships offering credit to customers. 
The smaller firms are also easier to study and approve or turn down, whereas the larger firms take more time to get to grips with. 
The biggest firms could have to wait for as long as a year before receiving full approval, as regulators want to prove they have cracked down on the much-criticised sector and so are putting the firms through their paces. 
The additional scrutiny comes at a difficult time for the sector, which is already reeling from a price cap . At the start of 2015 new rules came in which limit interest charges to 0.8pc per day, and cap late repayment fees at £15. 
As a result, customers should never end up paying more than twice their original debt. However, this has also pushed payday lenders to re-evaluate their risk models, only lending to the customers most able to repay the debt. 
The FCA and the firms involved declined to comment.
